topic.title: HP Helion OpenStack 2.0: Upgrading from Beta 2

body.p: Upgrade from Beta 2 is now supported. To perform the upgrade, you must have a working deployment of the Beta 2 release.
To perform the upgrade, follow the steps below. The upgrade will apply updates to HP Helion OpenStack services, as well as to the underlying cloud platform.

The upgrade mechanism included in this release is not complete in that it does not upgrade the full set of services in the HP Helion OpenStack stack. The following set of components are upgraded as part of the upgrade:
Linux for HP Helion
sosreport
monasca-agent
Openstack clients
haproxy/keepalived
Apache
Swift
Nova
Glance
Neutron
Cinder
Heat
Logging
Freezer If you are running a configuration based on the Beta 2 model configuration, you may still use that configuration after upgrading. However, a few changes are required.
body.note: The upgrade process is a live upgrade in the sense that VMs, volumes, network resources, etc. should survive the upgrade, but can't guarantee no-downtime of the APIs, although such downtime is minimized. If an upgrade requires a reboot, then the reboot is left to the operator/customer to handle. The upgrade process does not automatically reboot nodes.
body.p:
To upgrade, download the ISO as you would for the install.You will not be able to change your cloud model at this point, other than by adapting it as you did in beta1. You may have to merge your current configuration files with the new ones in step 3.
Log in to the deployer node as the user you created during the beta 2 deployment, and mount the new install media at /media/cdrom, for example: sudo mount hLinux-cattleprod-amd64-blaster-netinst-20150901-hlm.<build-date_sha1>.iso /media/cdrom
Unpack the following tarball: tar zxvf /media/cdrom/hos-2.0.0/hos-2.0.0-b.2-<whatever timestamp>.tgz Run the included initialization script to update the deployer ~/hos-2.0.0-b.2/hos-init.bash
Prepare the new Ansible tree for the upgrade task:
Identify any merge conflicts that may have arisen getting doing git status: cd ~/helion git status
Note that git status will also tell you what branch you are on. It should be the site branch. If git reports merge issues, resolve them by editing the files reported, then add and commit: git add --all . git commit -m "your commit message here" More information about git and the config processor can be found on the Using Git page.
Remove any data persisted from the Beta 1 deployment by executing these commands on the deployer node to delete the cp-persistent branch and all its persisted data, and recreate it. Then switch to the site branch: stack@hLinux:~$ cd helion stack@hLinux:~/helion$ git branch -D cp-persistent stack@hLinux:~/helion$ git checkout -b cp-persistent stack@hLinux:~/helion $ git checkout site
The recommended filesystem layout of for controller nodes has changed to provide better isolation for some services and to reapportion the capacity. The disk_controller.yml input file included comments to explain the recommended layout, which is based on a 500GB volume.
Copy the modified disks_controller.yml file into your cloud definition $ cp ~/helion/examples/entry-scale-with-vsa/data/disks_controller*.yml ~/helion/my_cloud/definition/dataand re-apply any local changes. Note that an alternative layout, disks_controller_1TB.yml, is now also provided for systems with a larger disc capacity. To use this instead, modify the ROLE_CONTROLLER entries in server_roles.yml to reference DISK_SET_CONTROLLER_1TB, as below:- name: ROLE-CONTROLLER interface-model: INTERFACE_SET_CONTROLLER disk-model: DISK_SET_CONTROLLER_1TB
Run the config processor: cd ~/helion/hos/ansible/ ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost config-processor-run.yml
Run the ready deployment script: ansible-playbook -i hosts/localhost ready-deployment.yml
Run the upgrade playbook: cd ~/scratch/ansible/next/hos/ansible ansible-playbook -i hosts/verb_hosts hlm-upgrade.yml
